;社交媒体影响者 Kai Cenat 面临煽动骚乱和促进非法集会的指控在纽约，这位在线主播吸引了数千名粉丝，其中许多是青少年，并承诺赠送电子产品，包括一台新的 PlayStation。该活动导致混乱，数十人被捕，其中一些人跳上汽车、投掷瓶子和拳打脚踢。

;

;塞纳特在收到一张出庭罚单后于周六早些时候从警方拘留所释放，该罚单由警方签发给要求嫌疑人出庭回答指控。警方发言人表示，塞纳特将于 8 月 18 日出庭。

;

;周五下午纽约联合广场发生的骚乱进一步凸显了社交媒体影响者对追随和奉承他们的人的控制力.

;

;“我们的孩子不能通过社交媒体抚养长大，”纽约市长埃里克·亚当斯 (Eric Adams) 周六在一次有关不相关犯罪的新闻发布会上表示。

;

;警方表示，他们逮捕了 65 人，其中包括30名青少年。多人受伤，其中一些人脸上流血。至少有四人被救护车带走。

;

;“我认为人们没有意识到我们在应对非常危险、不稳定的局势并能够将其提升到一定水平方面表现出的纪律程度。亚当斯说：“我们的决心没有造成任何生命损失或任何重大财产损失，也没有年轻人伤害自己。”

;

;流媒体赠品出现问题，纽约联合广场陷入混乱

;

;塞纳特21 岁的视频创作者在 Twitch 平台上拥有 650 万粉丝，他经常在该平台进行直播。他还在 YouTube 上拥有 400 万订阅者，他在 YouTube 上发布日常生活和喜剧视频博客，包括“假火盆厨师恶作剧！”他的最新视频“我在日本租给我们女朋友！”

;

;他的 299 个 YouTube 视频已获得超过 2.76 亿次观看。 12 月，他在第 12 届 Streamy Awards 颁奖典礼上荣获年度最佳主播奖。发送给他的公关人员、管理公司的消息以及用于业务咨询的电子邮件地址没有立即得到回复。

;

;随着活动的热度越来越高，塞纳特在车上通过 Twitch 进行直播，展示了他计划赠送的礼品卡。注意到人群和警察的存在，他敦促说：“在场的每个人，请确保你们的安全。 ......在安全之前我们不会采取任何行动。”

;

;最终，他和随行人员下了车，穿过人群，穿过街道，进入公园，塞纳特被包围了纽约警察局局长杰弗里·马德雷 (Jeffrey Maddrey) 表示，“为了安全”，塞纳特在下午的某个时候被带走，警方正在与他取得联系。社交媒体上发布的从新闻直升机拍摄的视频显示，塞纳特被抬过栅栏，脱离人群，然后被放入警车。

;

;空中电视新闻画面显示，拥挤的人群涌动，穿过人群。街道、公园里的鳞次栉比的建筑和混乱的交通。大声喊叫的青少年向车窗挥舞物体、投掷油漆罐并点燃灭火器。有些人爬上一辆行驶中的车辆，在车辆加速行驶时掉下来。其他人则冲上或爬上城市公交车。

;

;19 岁的斯凯拉克·琼斯 (Skylark Jones) 将这一场景比作“一部电影”，警察带着防暴装备赶到，并开始“向人们冲锋。”< /p>;

;琼斯和一位朋友一起到达，希望有机会获得其中一份赠品。他说，当他们到达时，现场已经挤满了人，甚至在塞纳特出现之前事情就变得不守规矩了。

;

;Maddrey 说三名警察受伤。

;

;“我们以前遇到过这样的事情但绝不会达到这种程度的危险。”Maddrey 说。

;

;“听着，我们并不反对年轻人玩得开心，我们也不反对年轻人聚集，”Maddrey 说。 “但不可能达到危险的程度。今天很多人受伤了。”

; Sun, 06 Aug 2023 03:20:02 +0800 In this ‘era of global boiling’, heat has become a health issue for the worldhttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3229916/era-global-boiling-heat-has-become-health-issue-world?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.06 03:00;

;上周，世界气象组织表示 7 月份“极有可能”成为有记录以来世界上最热的月份。对此，联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯宣称“全球沸腾时代已经到来”。

;

;与此同时，厄尔尼诺天气现象正在加剧气候变暖，科学家预测高温记录将再次被打破。明年就破了。厄尔尼诺现象是指每隔几年发生一次的海洋表面温度变暖，通常集中在赤道中东部太平洋地区。

;

;今年迄今为止，世界各地都出现了极端高温和天气。 7月16日，新疆三堡乡最高气温达到52.2摄氏度。几天后，北京连续27天气温超过35度。

;

;4月，马来西亚暂停户外活动在学校，由于天气炎热，穿着校服。在新加坡，5 月是有记录以来最热的月份，平均气温为 29.5 度，而新德里 5 月的气温高达 49 度，7 月则是 40 多年来最潮湿的一天。

;

;在欧洲、西班牙和葡萄牙遭受了与高温相关的过多死亡和热浪造成的农业破坏。 6月，法国大部分地区发布了红色和橙色热浪警报。

;

;7月，罗马达到41.8度的历史最高气温，撒丁岛和西西里岛也经历了强烈的热浪。罗德岛和科孚岛爆发山火后，希腊于本月底发布了第三次 46 度热浪警告。在北美，亚利桑那州凤凰城的每日最高气温破纪录，超过 43 度。

;

;幸运的是，凤凰城的空调一直在运转。如果没有，正如杰夫·古德尔在他的新书《热浪会首先杀死你》中警告的那样，热浪可能会成为掠夺性事件，往往会杀死最脆弱的群体。据估计，全球每年有超过 500 万人可能因过热或过冷而死亡。

;

;BBC 剧集《50 度的生活》生动地说明了与高温相关的死亡和痛苦被低估的情况。厄尔尼诺现象期间极端气温带来的风险增加，包括蚊子传播疾病和内乱的发生率增加。

;

;当我们的身体太热时，我们会出汗来降温。但是，在致命的热浪中，出汗已经不足以让我们的核心温度降至 37.5 度。如果没有喘息的机会，中暑就会出现头痛、头晕、痉挛、脉搏加快、恶心和口渴等症状。当体温达到或超过40度时，就会发生中暑，危及生命。

;

;企业还容易受到酷热带来的财务风险，例如生产损失。生活成本危机将对粮食供应和承受能力、供应链、就业和经济产生严重影响。

;

;许多人预计厄尔尼诺现象将进一步推高大宗商品价格和通货膨胀。热应激会导致无法进行户外工作，影响农业和农场动物的生长和生产力，影响水和粮食安全，并阻碍运输和工厂运营。

;

;干旱导致中国北方地区的玉米作物发育不良。承德，河南省中部地区的小麦遭受洪水破坏。去年中国遭遇60年来最严重的干旱，气温超过40度，影响了数亿人民的福祉。

;

;古特雷斯认为“领导人必须带头”。例如，在香港，政策制定者、城市规划者、学术界和非政府组织正在公共教育、卫生专业人员培训和应急准备方面进行合作。

;

;解决方案可以包括在供水和灌溉系统、干旱和干旱方面的支出。抗性种子，在室内生产更多食物并将牲畜转移到凉爽的棚屋中。

;

;必须实施就业法规以保护工人免受高温侵害。世界上最大的人道主义网络红十字会与红新月会国际联合会为城市制定了热浪指南。

;

;当地政治家可以执行降温计划并任命首席热官负责统一城市政府应对极端高温，加快防暑工作，启动减少极端高温风险和影响的工作。过热显然会影响最边缘化的人群。为了社会和自身的可持续发展，企业必须减少碳排放。

;

;从积极的方面来看，《柳叶刀》去年指出，中国可再生能源行业的就业人数持续增长，占到了全球就业人数的 40%。全球份额。然而，中国仍需要加速向碳中和经济转型，鼓励更多地将临床弱势群体纳入其健康和气候变化政策，并改善机构之间的合作。

;

;当我们展望未来时今年 11 月和 12 月在迪拜举行的联合国 COP28 气候变化会议上，我们将听到更多关于“全球向低排放和气候适应型世界转型”和“雄心勃勃的气候行动”的推动力。

;<需要采取全系统方法来减轻气候对全球健康的危害，并减少环境对卫生部门的负面影响。气候变化对健康的影响要求政府、企业、大学和社区与公共卫生领域的领导者透明地共享信息，以应对这一日益严重的紧急情况。

;

;无论是在气候变化、环境、社会和公司治理（ESG）领域， ）以及其他投资和干预措施，必须减少对健康的负面影响，我们还应该根据这种气候和公共卫生危机调整我们的行为。

;

;这将需要一个协调的、长期的长期努力寻找解决人类造成的环境问题的方法——我们必须共同努力寻找解决方案。

;周六，乌克兰无人机在黑海附近击中一艘俄罗斯油轮后，莫斯科承诺进行报复周五晚些时候，克里米亚发生了一天内第二次涉及无人机的海上袭击。

;

;周五早些时候，乌克兰袭击了俄罗斯的一个主要港口。

;

;莫斯科强烈谴责其所认为的乌克兰“恐怖分子”俄罗斯外交部发言人玛丽亚·扎哈罗娃表示，“刻赤海峡的一艘民用船只遭到袭击”。

;

;“这种野蛮行径是没有道理的，他们不会不予回应，行凶者和肇事者将不可避免地受到惩罚。”受到惩罚，”她在 Telegram 消息应用程序上写道。

;

;随着基辅海军能力的增强，黑海正成为战争中越来越重要的战场。

;

;三周前，莫斯科撤军一项重要的出口协议允许乌克兰通过黑海运送数百万吨粮食在世界市场上出售。撤军后，俄罗斯对包括敖德萨在内的乌克兰港口进行了多次袭击。

;

;乌克兰安全部门的一名官员向美联社证实，该部门是对正在运输油轮的袭击的幕后黑手。为俄罗斯军队提供燃料。这位官员补充说，这次袭击使用了一架装载了 450 公斤（992 磅）TNT 的海上无人机。该官员要求匿名，因为他无权发表官方声明。

;

;“The Sig俄罗斯联邦海洋和河流运输局在 Telegram 上写道：“油轮……右舷水线附近的机舱出现一个洞，可能是海上无人机袭击造成的。”并补充说，11 名船员没有伤亡

;

;克里姆林宫派驻乌克兰部分占领的南部扎波罗热地区的官员弗拉基米尔·罗戈夫 (Vladimir Rogov) 表示，几名船员被碎玻璃炸伤。

;

;俄罗斯化学品船在乌克兰海上无人机袭击

;

;乌克兰安全部门负责人瓦西里·马柳克没有具体说明乌克兰对此次无人机袭击负责，但他表示，“此类特种行动是在乌克兰领海进行的，完全合法。” ”他说，任何此类爆炸都是“对敌人而言绝对合乎逻辑且有效的步骤。”

;

;这次袭击使刻赤大桥上的交通以及渡轮运输短暂中断。

;<据俄罗斯塔斯社报道，拖船被部署来协助这艘油轮，该油轮因帮助在叙利亚作战的俄罗斯军队提供喷气燃料而受到美国制裁。

;

;乌克兰早些时候对新罗西斯克的袭击导致海上交通中断。这场冲突持续了几个小时，这是俄罗斯商业港口首次成为这场持续近 18 个月冲突的目标。该港口拥有海军基地、造船厂和石油码头，是出口的关键。它位于克里米亚以东约 110 公里（约 60 英里）处。

;

;航运专家 Jayendu Krishna 告诉美联社，袭击使俄罗斯航运活动“基本上未受到影响”。他认为，它们可能会增加俄罗斯袭击乌克兰港口的风险，而不是成为向俄罗斯施加压力以停止袭击并恢复粮食协议的工具。

;

;“每当俄罗斯发生任何事情时，你都会看到普京处于报复模式......因此，你可能会看到对乌克兰其他地区的进一步袭击，”克里希纳说。

;

;“我认为这可能会加剧影响并加剧黑海的风险，而不是减少它，”他补充道。 “我很难想象俄罗斯会屈服，除非他们的银行运营顺利，并且他们能够不间断地出口自己的货物。”

;

;周六，一名副手在 Telegram 上发帖俄罗斯安理会主席梅德韦杰夫暗示，俄罗斯将加大对乌克兰港口的攻击力度，以回应基辅在黑海袭击俄罗斯船只的事件：

;

;“显然，对敖德萨、伊兹梅尔等地的袭击对他们来说这还不够。”他写道。

;

;在其他事态发展中，俄罗斯国防部周六表示，它在乌克兰最东部的卢甘斯克地区占领了一个定居点，该地区大部分被俄罗斯占领。该部在 Telegram 上写道：“在库皮扬斯克地区……新沃塞利夫斯克定居点被解放。”

;

;沙特主办乌克兰和平谈判，以成为全球调解人

;

;在其他地方，两个国家为期一天的寻求和平解决战争的峰会在沙特阿拉伯拉开帷幕。

;

;来自约 40 个国家（但不包括俄罗斯）的高级官员将致力于就如何结束冲突的关键原则达成一致。

;

; p>;

;“这非常重要，因为在粮食安全等问题上，非洲、亚洲和世界其他地区数百万人的命运直接取决于世界执行和平方案的速度， ”乌克兰总统泽连斯基谈到这次峰会时说道。 “我感谢沙特阿拉伯提供这个谈判平台。”

;

;出席吉达峰会的乌克兰主要特使、乌克兰总统首席助手安德烈·叶尔马克 (Andriy Yermak) 在周五晚上发表的电视采访中谈到了此次会谈在他的 Telegram 账户上：“我预计对话会很困难，但我们背后是真相，我们背后是善良，”他说。

;

;在评论沙特阿拉伯的会谈时，扎哈罗娃告诉俄罗斯官方媒体：在没有莫斯科参与的情况下就冲突做出决定的想法是“荒谬的”。尽管如此，她说，代表们有“充分的创造力”来讨论这个问题。

; Sat, 05 Aug 2023 23:20:03 +0800 China-Italy ties: as Rome looks for belt and road exit it’s expected to be ‘punished twice’ without reaping benefitshttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3230025/china-italy-ties-rome-looks-belt-and-road-exit-its-expected-be-punished-twice-without-reaping?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.05 23:00;
;;

;意大利参与中国国家主席习近平的旗舰外交政策工具“一带一路”倡议，即将结束，罗马预计将在今年年底前结束这场为期四年的传奇。

;

;意大利总理乔治亚·梅洛尼 (Giorgia Meloni) 不再续签 2019 年签署的谅解备忘录将确保没有一个国家既是七国集团的成员，又是中国基础设施富矿的成员。

;

;上周，意大利国防部长吉多·克罗塞托(Guido Crosetto)称，棺材上的最后一颗钉子似乎已敲定。加入该倡议的决定是“即兴而残暴的”。

;

;梅洛尼上周在华盛顿会见美国总统乔·拜登后，预计将于秋季前往北京，亲自向习近平解释这一决定。

;

;The writing has been on the wall for some time. Even on the campaign trail, Meloni described the decision to join as a “big mistake”. Managing the fallout of the situation, however, puts the country's first far-right leader since World War II in an unenviable position.

;

;The decision comes as most of western Europe is trying to rebalance ties with China. But while Brussels has left its de-risking strategy deliberately vague – partly to offer EU members diplomatic cover when disentangling themselves from parts of the Chinese supply chain – no such ambiguity is available to Meloni.

;

;“The issue for Italy right now is how to move out of the [belt and road], which is a political and not an economic tool, while maintaining or maybe strengthening the economic links with China. That is the challenge Meloni faces,” said Lorenzo Codogno, chief economist at the Italian Ministry of Economy and Finance from 2006 to 2015.

;

;In effect, Italy faces being punished twice for joining the initiative, and without harvesting any of the economic rewards it might have hoped for.

;

;“When we signed the memorandum, we didn't get any significant economic advantage. And now, since the overall geopolitical context is forcing us to go out, we again lose. We first lost reputationally as far as Western countries were concerned. Now, we lose reputation in the eyes of China,” said Giuliano Noci, vice-rector at the Politecnico di Milano university and a former adviser to the Italian government on infrastructure matters.

;

;Noci said that signing up to the belt and road programme without any side deals that would have, for example, granted Italian goods better access to the Chinese market was “a mistake”. “Why can German products enter the market and ours not?” he asked.

;

;This sort of logic was rife at the time. In 2019, Luigi Di Miao, then economy minister, said the reason for joining was to rebalance the trade deficit.

;

;“Our goal with these accords is to start to rebalance an imbalance for which there is a lot of 'made in China' coming to Italy and too little 'made in Italy' that goes to China,” Di Maio said, adding that he expected “a substantial and gradual increase of exports and we hope that in the next years we can balance out the trade imbalances”.

;

;The country suffered three recessions in a decade and was looking enviously at France and Germany, both of which enjoyed much more profitable relations with Beijing.

;

;“At the time, many Italians felt abandoned by Europe, while its populist government was sceptical of the European Union and more than willing to turn to China to fulfil its investment needs,” wrote David Sacks, a fellow for Asia studies at the Council on Foreign Relations, in a recent blog post.

;

;The data shows an increase in overall trade, but the deficit was not rebalanced, nor did investment flow.

;

;From 2018, the year before former prime minister Giuseppe Conte on-boarded Italy, to 2022, Chinese investments in Italy dropped by 81 per cent, according to statistics from Rhodium Group, a research house.

;

;Calculations based on Chinese customs data show that while in the first half of this year, Italy's exports to China were 31.7 per cent higher than the equivalent period in 2018, imports from China surged 40.24 per cent, actually expanding the trade deficit by 55 per cent.

;

;Italy defence minister: joining China's belt and road plan an 'atrocious' decision

;

;Observers caution crediting a memorandum that was light on specifics with a two-way surge in trade. Others bemoan the continued focus on trade balances as a metric of economic well-being.

;

;“You don't get anything by signing up to the [belt and road] – it's a gesture of goodwill that may or may not make Beijing more likely to reward you. It's a necessary step in the right direction if you're looking to get closer to China and find funding for infrastructure projects, but it's not anything like a 'deal' or 'treaty,'” said Jacob Mardell, an analyst of EU-China relations based in Berlin.

;

;For China, losing Italy – the belt and road's richest Western member and a key node on the original Silk Road – will be a symbolic blow, even if not unexpected.

;

;Coinciding with his state visit four years ago, Xi wrote that the agreement would “cultivate the soil of bilateral relations and ensure that it can come to a new and richer flowering”.

;

;But even then, a new geopolitical reality was setting in. Eleven days before the agreement was signed, the EU branded China a “systemic rival” in a now infamous paper that established its triptych policy towards the world's second-largest economy.

;

;The coronavirus pandemic was just around the corner. Add to this Russia's war on Ukraine, and Europe's relationship with China has been in a downwards spiral since Conte signed on the dotted line.

;

;“This could not happen today,” Codogno said. “Politically, today it would be unthinkable, especially after the Russian invasion of Ukraine.”

;

;For a decade, China's approach to expanding the belt and road was to target “pivot” or “lighthouse” countries, that would set a positive example to their neighbours, said Moritz Rudolf, an expert in the initiative at Yale Law School's Paul Tsai China Centre.

;

;“But with Europe that just doesn't work any more. With the geopolitical situation, this just wouldn't happen today. We are in a time of reorientation with China. Economic relations are now viewed in terms of dependencies rather than opportunities,” Rudolf said.

;

;In 2019, Europe was caught between a rock and a hard place, with the new thinking on China clashing with frosty transatlantic ties with the government of then US president Donald Trump.

;

;“Italy is a major global economy and a great investment destination. Endorsing [the belt and road] lends legitimacy to China's predatory approach to investment and will bring no benefits to the Italian people,” the White House's National Security Council said in a tweet at the time.

;

;But now, with friendlier ties with a Biden administration that has adopted a similarly hawkish stance on China, there is even less room to manoeuvre.

;

;“Once the renewal of the memorandum became a public and international matter, it was not possible for Italy to avoid taking a political decision,” said Francesca Ghiretti, a Brussels-based researcher of EU-China economic ties at the Mercator Institute of China Studies. “It became extremely difficult for that decision not to be turned into a geopolitical issue in the tensions between the US and China.”

;

;On Friday, the Chinese foreign ministry warned that “some forces continue to maliciously hype, politicise the Sino-Italian joint construction of the belt and road” while expanding on the economic benefits of taking part.

;

;Disquiet in EU ranks as 'de-risking' strategy for China pushes ahead

;

;Meloni said that during her trip to Washington last week, Biden did not raise the issue. But her own rhetoric on the matter has grown more taciturn, as fears rise in Rome of repercussions from Beijing.

;

;Looking to recent history, she may be hoping to emulate Latvia and Estonia, rather than Lithuania.

;

;The former pair of Baltic nations left China's 16+1 grouping last year with little fanfare and faced no retaliation beyond a diplomatic dressing down. Lithuania, however, which left noisily and sought to simultaneously deepen ties with Taiwan, has become embroiled in a prolonged feud with Beijing.

;

;“Beijing reads the Italian decision to not renew the MOU as a victory for the US,” Ghiretti said. “If we consider that and the public profile of this story, targeted and symbolic retaliation is not off the table – even if members who left the 16+1, for example, were not subject to it.”

;

;The companies had sought the FDA's approval for the drug, Zurzuvae, to treat major depressive disorder (MDD), or clinical depression, as well as post-partum depression, which affect millions of people.

;

;PPD severely affects a woman's ability to return to normal functioning, while also potentially affecting the mother's relationship with her child.

;

;“Zurzuvae is expected to launch and be commercially available in the fourth quarter of 2023 soon following scheduling as a controlled substance by the US Drug Enforcement Administration, which is anticipated to occur within 90 days,” Sage Therapeutics and Biogen said in a statement.

;

;

;The statement said the FDA issued a Complete Response Letter for the New Drug Application for Zurzuvae in the treatment of adults with MDD. ;

;Sage and Biogen said they were reviewing the feedback and evaluating next steps.

;

;Analysts have anticipated that the stocks of both companies would fall if the drug was approved only for post-partum depression, due to the smaller patient population.

;

;Until now, the FDA said, treatment for post-partum depression was available only as an intravenous injection.

;

;In 2021, an estimated 21 million adults in the United States had at least one episode of major depressive disorder, which is characterised by a persistent feeling of sadness. PPD affects around one in seven women who give birth.

;Before the inspection, the captain, a man, had returned from a training session with a female first officer on the night of July 20, both publications said.

;

;The technician was told to remain silent after reporting the discovery to a supervisor, they added.

;

;West Wu Wai-hung, controller of the Government Flying Service, told the Post he had received no complaints over the incident but stressed the organisation expected its staff to conduct themselves according to a “very high standard”.

;

;He had immediately met those involved to get a better understanding of the situation, he added.

;

;“There was no evidence to prove that any illegal, improper behaviours that affect aviation safety had occurred. The incident was caused by the gross negligence of the captain when handling his personal belongings,” Wu said.

;

;The controller said the service had handled the situation according to procedure as the matter could cause misunderstandings and affect the flying squad's professional reputation.

;

;The dangerous, life-saving missions of Hong Kong's Government Flying Service

;

;The crew member involved had been issued an advisory letter and received a verbal reprimand, which warned against behaving in any way that undermined the flying squad's reputation, he said.

;

;Wu added that an internal circular was sent out to all aircrew, reminding them to carefully check all personal belongings and devices brought on board and ensure they were relevant to the flight operation.

;;2023.08.05 22:00;
;;

;Some 84 hours before a magnitude 7.2 earthquake struck off the Alaska Peninsula on July 16, a team of researchers in China may have seen the quake coming but could not pinpoint where and when it would hit.

;

;Now they hope to broaden their research net to make more accurate quake predictions possible.

;

;Zhang Maosheng, a professor and dean at Xian Jiaotong University in Shaanxi province and a researcher for China's Ministry of Natural Resources, received a text alert declaring an abnormal data reading a few days before the Alaskan quake occurred.

;

;On receiving the alert, he knew an earthquake was on its way, and that it would be of a significant magnitude. Yet, he did not know its location or exact timing.

;

;After 10 years of observing data, knowing that an earthquake will happen but not having enough information to warn the world is a familiar feeling for the professor.

;

;Zhang and his team cannot predict earthquakes – which would include knowing the magnitude, location, date and time – but they do believe their discoveries so far could make it possible in future.

;

;A paper published in the Chinese journal Northwestern Geology in June revealed that the research team had spent more than a decade examining possible precursors to earthquakes.

;

;Using high-precision gravimeters the team has captured data from dozens of earthquakes since 2010, including the devastating Turkey-Syria earthquake on February 6.

;

;The paper introduces the monitoring of the Earth's gravitational field at low frequencies as a potential precursor for predicting high-magnitude “short-impending”, or imminent, earthquakes.

;

;So-called precursors are abnormal events that happen before earthquakes that may suggest a quake will occur, such as a series of smaller earthquakes or unusual activity in animals, according to the United States Geological Survey (USGS).

;

;Through monitoring changes in dynamic gravity, the team stumbled on a possible precursor as well as a potential four-phase mechanism for short-impending earthquakes.

;

;In particular, during the second or “locked energy storage” phase – which usually happens between 1 and 15 days before an earthquake – anomalies in dynamic gravity are seen through peaks in the gravity readings.

;

;The team observed the abnormalities using a gravimeter, an instrument that typically measures changes in the Earth's absolute gravity.

;

;They developed their own dynamic gravimeter using liquid suspension to measure abnormalities based on the liquid's motion. The researchers said it was more accurate for short-term earthquake prediction, as well as more cost-effective and mobile.

;

;An anomalous reading was observed 83 hours before a magnitude 7.4 earthquake in Sulawesi, Indonesia, in September 2018 and 116 hours before a magnitude 7.2 earthquake in Tajikistan in February.

;

;The team said that while peaks in dynamic gravity showed that an earthquake would happen within a short window of time, and the magnitude could be suggested through the peak strength, they were still unable to scientifically identify the exact time and location.

;

;The USGS states that earthquake predictions must include the time, location and magnitude. It is adamant that no scientist has ever predicted a major earthquake.

;

;Despite not being able to fully identify these elements, the research team has consistently been able to see signs of major earthquakes days before they happen, according to Zhang who said that for earthquakes above magnitude 7, “the accuracy is 100 per cent”.

;

;Explainer | A closer look at tremor reports in Hong Kong amid string of quakes

;

;For these high-magnitude earthquakes, “as long as we see a peak, there will be an earthquake after”, according to author Liu Huaqing, a professor at Northwestern Polytechnical University in Xian in Shaanxi province.

;

;The authors of the paper said earthquake forecasting had been a focus for China since the 1950s, and that in the 1970s several earthquakes were forecast and casualties reduced.

;

;However, failures to predict major earthquakes since have caused countries to shift away from prediction.

;

;Liu said that while scientists in countries such as the united States and Japan did not believe earthquakes could be predicted, “at least for some earthquakes, we do not agree with this point of view”.

;

;The team started observing the dynamic gravity data after noticing a relationship between the anomalous readings and earthquakes. They are not under a government mandate to conduct prediction research, and have conducted the research voluntarily.

;

;In the paper, the team shared the log of group chat messages where, five days before the Tajikistan earthquake, an anomalous reading was noted along with the forecast that an earthquake could happen in three days.

;

;The Turkey-Syria earthquake in February is included as one of the 11 observed earthquakes in the paper, and it was the team's first time seeing two anomalous peaks occurring one after the other.

;

;“At the time [we] hadn't encountered this before” Zhang said. That day, after the initial magnitude 7.8 earthquake happened, it was followed by another magnitude 7.5 quake.

;

;“At the time, we really did not think there would be two earthquakes” he said, adding that after the two quakes occurred the team believed the double peaks related to the two separate earthquakes.

;

;Liu said that after a decade of monitoring the anomalies he was accustomed to seeing large peaks and knowing a large earthquake was coming.

;

;The team observes earthquakes above magnitude 6.5. Their previous criterion of reports for earthquakes above magnitude 2 initiated hundreds of text alerts a minute, according to Zhang.

;

;Zhang said more observation was needed to see the relationship between quakes and the timing of advance peaks because anomalies in dynamic gravity occurred over a range of time before earthquakes happened.

;

;He said that in terms of potential earthquake prediction, a range of 1 to 15 days was “already very accurate” and beyond anything else that existed in forecasting or prediction research right now.

;

;When asked in an interview why this research was released after many years, Zhang said: “We have not solved the issue, but this might be able to and the probability is high.”

;

;What living on the fault line means for China's Sichuan province

;

;The main issue the team faces now is using the information from the precursor to establish the exact time and location of the earthquakes. Zhang said there was “an issue of coverage” for the machines. They have just four set up in Xian.

;

;Zhang said the precursor activity could transmit long distances across the Earth, allowing the team to see all high-magnitude earthquakes from Xian.

;

;The unique geographical conditions of their main observation point, which lies under a mountain, also allows for great stability. However, they cannot judge distance with these machines alone.

;

;He said their goal was to collaborate with researchers and countries to set up gravimeter machines around the world to create a network of coverage and data collection.

;

;The team also aimed to assess whether the expanded monitoring of this precursor could predict earthquakes by pinpointing the time and location before they happened.

;

;If scientists and organisations are interested, Liu said the machines could be produced quickly. He said the team had already been contacted by many researchers in China since releasing the paper.

;

;“If proven by many people, it will be a very important scientific discovery for earthquake prediction,” said geotechnical engineering professor Yue Zhongqi from the University of Hong Kong, who was not associated with the study.

;

;Yue said more research and testing was needed to see if this precursor was consistent and only linked with earthquakes, however it appeared encouraging as “a unique precursor”.

;

;He said experts in the field were not surprised when potential precursors were found – and many had been claimed – making it important to show how many successful predictions a precursor could make.

;

;Meng Xingmin, dean of the school of earth sciences at Lanzhou University in Gansu province, said the paper was “an innovative study in the international earthquake research community”.
